dt: {bc}pronunciation and enunciation of words in singing
{bc}choice of words especially with regard to correctness, clearness, or effectiveness

quotes.t: He has wisely chosen to render almost all the material in what novelists and writers of creative nonfiction like to call "close third person," approximating the {qword}diction{/qword} and consciousness of his characters but retaining the freedom to wander into the bigger picture.
No one is better than Didion at using flatness of affect and formality of {qword}diction{/qword} to convey seething anger and disdain.

When he sang Anatol in the world premiere of Samuel Barber's {it}Vanessa{/it}, in 1958, Gedda's performance received high marks for impeccable {qword}diction{/qword} and enunciation—in that mostly American cast, he was the only principal whose English could be understood.

et: earlier, "word, phrase," going back to Middle English {it}dicion{/it} "saying," borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French {it}dictyoun{/it} "word," borrowed from Latin {it}dictiōn-, dictiō{/it} "act of speaking, speech, (in grammar) word, expression, form," from {it}dic-,{/it} variant stem of {it}dīcere{/it} "to talk, speak, say, utter" + {it}-tiōn-, -tiō,{/it} suffix of action nouns; {it}dīcere{/it} going back to Indo-European {it}*dei̯ḱ-{/it} "show, point out," whence also, with varying ablaut, Germanic {it}*tīh-a-{/it} "point out" (whence Old English {it}tēon{/it} "to accuse," Old Saxon af{it}tīhan{/it} "to deny," Old High German {it}zīhan{/it} "to accuse," Old Norse {it}tjā, tēa{/it} "to show, report," Gothic ga{it}teihan{/it} "to announce, tell"), Greek {it}deíknȳmi, deiknýnai{/it} "to show, point out," Sanskrit {it}diśati{/it} "(s/he) shows, exhibits"
shortdef: pronunciation and enunciation of words in singing
choice of words especially with regard to correctness, clearness, or effectiveness
